pros:
There are growth opportunities for those who look for them within Saint Joseph Health System. It is a small community, and the more familiar one becomes with their surrounding departments, the more expansive and collaborative their work becomes. 
SJHS has a lot of great initiatives and ways to get involved, and, in my experience, there are great supervisors who encourage their colleagues to learn and grow.
cons:
I think Healthcare is tough right now. Staffing can be a challenge, finances can be a challenge, access to hospital services can be a challenge. 
Any barrier that is brought to the table is open for discussion, and leadership is open to hearing ideas for solving problems.

pros:

There are systems in place to make official complaints not just about patient safety but for harrassment of staff

review_title: By far, the best place to be employed, period
pros:
1)  Managment and upper management are supportive of us and our initiatives.  They also recognize exceptional performance in associates and grow employees
2)  I feel like we have very modern, up-to-date equipment that is top of the line, and when needed, there is access to capital purchases to provide the state-of-the art
3)  The benefits packages are the best I've seen at any employer.
4)  The Electronic Health Record, and the IT services and applications are definitely the best in the country.   Much attention is paid to process flows, work flows, and education of staff.
5)  Being part of a larger National network of hospitals is good because you can transfer to a new location if desired.   Also, it seems like the larger corporation helps give direction on things and we are not always inventing things from scratch
6)  You can notice the Catholic influence in the way that we dedicate effort to the poor and uninsured.  There is always attention to make sure the mission is truly the focus.
cons: I cannot honestly think of a single con, this place is where I want to spend the rest of my career!

pros:
As someone else in these reviews said, "The checks cash".
New but dysfunctional building - seems all the way finding signs are poor and it's easy to get lost and you can't find the nurses.
cons:
Many, many, many.  I've been in nursing for more than 20 years and at this hospital for about 5 of them.  Every few years they change out top management & they're way over due.  The current "C-Suite" is about as dysfunctional as I have ever seen.  They talk a good game but that's about it.
I have just accepted a job "across the river" at the better hospital.  My soon to be new employer has a solid Leadership team and much more stable.  Anyone looking to work at St. Joe's should first try to get in Beacon.

pros: They claim to be a Catholic Mission-driven hospital.  Before you jump to a conclusion, please see the Cons section below.  They have plenty of job openings.
cons:
Where do I begin?  First the culture of safety is dangerously low. They conduct (rather their parent company Trinity conducts) an annual culture of safety survey.  They did poorly last year and rumor (highly qualified) says they really, really sunk to a new level this year.
This is purely a sign of BAD leadership.  I can assure you that the executive suite is full of poor leaders.  Since I am clinical, I can say with certainty that the CNO is one of the poorest leaders I've known.
I went to him to talk about all the patient falls we are having and he just blew me off and threatened me with discipline if I talked about it .... well try to get me!  I will be leaving soon anyway.

pros: Friendly, caring co-workers; fair compensation
cons: RNs are expected to be able to independently care for critically ill patients (including neonates) after only 8 weeks of orientation, even without any prior ICU experience. If the RN is unable to independently provide all care.....even when assigned to a patient with a condition the RN has never experienced before or knows anything about....the management's response is to terminate the RN. I have witnessed this on more than one or two occasions. This promotes unsafe nursing practice that places the patients' lives and the nurses' licenses in jeopardy.

job_title: Licensed Practical Nurse in Mishawaka, IN
pros: Benefits were OK. That's all I have.
cons:
The moment when the upper management used the phrase "Leave your opinions at the door" during orientation I knew this place wasn't for me. I worked 10-12 hours a day on average when I was only to work 8. It may have just been the clinic I was at but I saw no real actions for improvement, considering the problem was the doctor. What is the point of having computer documentation if the doctor doesn't do anything in it? 
I was hired for my expertise and to share my knowledge on teamwork within the workplace, but my ideas were always rejected and the doctor questioned everything I did, even when I showed proof from sources such as the CDC stating what was correct. 
Be prepared to pray EVERYWHERE, regardless of what you believe.

review_title: I didn't want to do this but .... please read
pros: Their pay scale are fair - only fair as they haven't given us a pay increase in 2 years
cons:
It's always about leadership and I can honestly say there is none at SJ Med.
They have an ego centered CEO - he's a little like Trump.  It's obvious to all that he picked weak VPs.
They in turn picked weak directors, etc, etc.  Poorly run and a dangerous place to be if you're a patient.

review_title: Not very good - some bad players at the top - they can turn on you in an instant......
pros: They pay fairly well - that doesn't look so good over time because of the stressful effort you expend watching your back and CYing Your A.
cons: Management turns around like a revolving door in Macy's during the Christmas Holidays.  They claim to follow a Catholic Mission - yeah right.  Many good people have been cannon-balled out of there - just because they can .........

pros: Hired in easily.  There are 2 campuses - really separate hospitals and cultures.  Pay is average.  If you have opportunity, choose the Plymouth Campus - not the Mishawaka one.
cons:
Plymouth - none really.  Good management team there.
Mishawaka - where do I begin.  Totally dysfunctional upper management.  They are engrossed in their internal politics and don't care much for patients.  I've been there 2 years and am trying to get out.  Poorly managed patient care hospital.

pros: Fairly large facility so opportunity to move around is there.  Pay in clinical is competitive but not in support service areas.
cons:
Very political place and most people are in great fear about keeping their jobs. Fear is not a good motivating environment.  There’s a lot of spies who are willing to blow the whistle on you. 
I left this place and am glad I did.  Thank goodness the economy let me do that.

pros: have to really stretch to think of one ....... pays in US $$
cons:
I have been here for ten + years and desperately want to work somewhere else.  I'd love to work
across the river at our competition.  This place has very very poor leadership - especially from the CEO on down.  It hurts to say this - but it's soooo true.

pros:
beautiful, modern facility
Human Resources is generally fair, and the staff go above and beyond to be helpful
cons: Weak, ineffective (current day and past) CEO.  Current day CEO is inappropriate with females in the workplace.  Nursing is not appropriately respected or compensated.  Marketing leadership is notoriously vile to work with and ineffective.  (local ads are a laughingstock).   "Problem" Physicians are not controlled or reprimanded.  Overall NOT a respectful place to work.

review_title: Not Associate concerned company. All about $$$   not even about great healthcare any longer.

review_title: I have worked at SJRMC for over 13 years - won't work at any other hospital in the area.
pros: Faith-based; caring people; committed employees; I work with the best team & have a great manager.
cons: As with all big companies, sometimes the communication can be a bit slow.

review_title: Like going home.  Felt very comfortable, safe and secure.

pros: Pay Checks clear - for now at least.
